title.rendered: Vaughan Handyman: Converting Your Basement into an Efficient Home Office

content.rendered:
Many people are working remotely from home. Unfortunately, most houses, especially older homes, were not intended to accommodate a professional life. Traditionally, homes offered solace from the busyness of work and school, giving families the time they needed for personal connection and freedom. Depending on your job, home office storage and function take space, often space your house doesn’t have readily available.

Your home may have one area of untapped potential: The basement. A professional carpenter can help you plan out the area within the existing footprint to designate and create a legitimate home office, not an amalgamation of several areas, such as a living room that acts as a homework, play, and TV room.

Turning a basement into a functioning office space where you feel productive and want to work takes time and planning. Discover how to make your basement work for your future office.

How To Arrange a Basement for Office Storage and Function

A basement office renovation is not among the most challenging of all the possible custom home renovation projects you can tackle. You don’t need to worry about plumbing or other complex systems for a basement office; you mainly need lighting and privacy.

If your family uses the basement, it is important to consider how the office will layout in the space. Most basements have staircases that create a natural division. You can use the stairs to create one barrier to your office, leaving the other half of the basement to the family.

Remember the difference between finished and framing measurements when measuring out your office. If you want an office with an interior space of 10ft by 10ft, the exterior perimeter will be larger. You must consider the framing and drywall in your measurements.

Also, you need to plan for outlet and lighting placement. Sometimes, homeowners can use the existing lighting in a space and work with a professional to erect walls. However, in older homes, a carpenter and electrician may need to work in tandem to determine the proper placement of outlets and lighting.

If your family uses the basement and the surrounding area is not only used for home office storage, you should also consider insulation and soundproofing. Soundproofing will ensure your office is quiet, allowing for focus. The quality and amount of soundproofing depends on individual needs. A solid office door can also contribute to the quietness of a space.

Importance of Hiring a Handyman in Vaughan

If it is not clear by now, a basement renovation is hard work and requires much planning before construction begins. A professional handyman and carpenter in Vaughan should be your first phone call after deciding you want a home office in the basement.

A professional is familiar with building codes and permits. They also have the qualifications and insurance to protect homeowners against liabilities, such as injuries or property damage. Also, an experienced and licensed professional provides homeowners with a level of confidence they will not get from DIY efforts.

Finally, if you want your new home office to be a value-add to your property, it must be legal. Unpermitted installations and add-ons are usually a value loss because they cannot be figured into a home’s sale price.

How Handyman Connection Can Help With Storage Solutions For Your Office

If you want more home office storage or a space to work remotely without interruption, look no further than your basement. Basements offer bonus square footage to most homeowners, and with the help of a professional contractor, you can install a home office suitable for any job. Contact Handyman Connection to schedule a consultation with a handyman in Vaughan and learn more about what the renovation will consist of.
